verses.text: It is good to give thanks to the LORD, to sing praises to Your name, O Most High;
verses.comment: This psalm opens with the moral good of thanksgiving. The use of 'Most High' echoes Melchizedek’s blessing in Genesis 14:18, underlining God's transcendence.

verses.text: to declare Your lovingkindness in the morning, and Your faithfulness at night,
verses.comment: The daily rhythm of praise prefigures regular, liturgical prayer, seen later in both synagogue and Church traditions.

verses.text: with a ten-stringed instrument and harp, with melody on the lyre.
verses.comment: Musical worship is closely tied to Temple and later Church liturgies, showing praise is both spiritual and physical.

verses.text: For You, LORD, have made me rejoice by Your works. I sing for joy at the works of Your hands.
verses.comment: Joy here is a fruit of acknowledging God’s creation and providence, themes fulfilled in Christ as the new creation (2 Cor. 5:17).

verses.text: How great are Your works, O LORD! How profound Your thoughts!
verses.comment: God’s works and wisdom surpass human understanding; see St. Paul applying this attitude of awe to Christ’s salvific plan (Rom. 11:33).

verses.text: A senseless man does not know, and a fool does not understand this:
verses.comment: Spiritual understanding is a gift. In Catholic tradition, the sacraments impart grace that enlightens the heart rather than relying on mere intellectual knowledge.

verses.text: When the wicked sprout like grass and all evildoers flourish, it is that they may be destroyed forever.
verses.comment: The fate of the wicked, who flourish briefly before judgment, is later echoed by Christ in the parable of the weeds (Matt. 13:30).

verses.text: But You, O LORD, are exalted forever.
verses.comment: God’s eternal kingship anticipates Christ’s everlasting reign (Heb. 1:8) recognized both by all Christian traditions.

verses.text: For behold, Your enemies, O LORD, for behold, Your enemies shall perish; all evildoers shall be scattered.
verses.comment: The fate of God’s enemies is certain, pointing to the justice of God which is fully revealed at Christ’s return.

verses.text: But You have raised my horn like that of a wild ox; I am anointed with fresh oil.
verses.comment: 'Horn' is a symbol of strength and victory; 'anointed with oil' foreshadows Christ (the Anointed One), and by extension, sacramental anointing in the Church.

verses.text: My eyes have seen the defeat of my enemies; my ears have heard of the downfall of those who rise up against me.
verses.comment: Deliverance and victory are guarantees for the faithful, as ultimately realized in Jesus' resurrection and final victory over sin.

verses.text: The righteous will flourish like the palm tree and grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
verses.comment: Flourishing trees symbolize the lasting fruitfulness of the righteous. This imagery also appears in monastic and contemplative life rooted in the Church.

verses.text: Those who are planted in the house of the LORD will flourish in the courts of our God.
verses.comment: To dwell in God’s house foreshadows the Church as the new Temple (1 Cor. 3:16). In Catholic interpretation, this verse hints at the security and fruitfulness found within the visible community of faith.

verses.text: They will still bear fruit in old age; they will remain fresh and green,
verses.comment: Perseverance in holiness leads to lasting vitality. The Church teaches holiness is a life-long pursuit, and even the aged play important spiritual roles (cf. the saints and elders).

verses.text: to declare that the LORD is upright; He is my rock, and there is no unrighteousness in Him.
verses.comment: The psalm ends affirming God's unchanging righteousness. Only God is completely upright—later revealed in Christ the cornerstone (Eph. 2:20).
